course.title: Political Rhetoric and American Democracy
course.description: This course investigates a question at the heart of democratic politics: in what sense, if any, is rhetoric a part of reasoned political argument? Is rhetoric necessarily a kind of pandering or manipulation? Or can rhetoric be a part of thoughtful deliberation on the common good? We will examine the case for and against rhetoric by turning to classical texts (Aristotle, Plato, Hobbes, Kant), contemporary political theory, and great political speeches (Frederick Douglass, Abraham Lincoln, Lyndon Johnson, and others.)
